revision.text:
{{pp-vandalism|small=yes}} {{other people}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2011}} {{Infobox comedian | name = Bill Maher | image = BillMaherSept10.jpg | caption = Maher receiving his star on
[[Hollywood Walk of Fame]], September 2010 | birth_name = William MaherStated on ''[[Finding Your Roots]]'', January 12, 2016, PBS; on a series that lists "Jr." and "Sr." distinctions, Bill Maher's birth name was listed simply as William Maher, while his father was William Aloysius Maher Jr., and his paternal grandfather was William Aloysius Maher Sr. | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1956|1|20}} | birth_place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | medium = Stand-up comedy, television, film, books | education = [[Pascack Hills High School]] | alma_mater = [[Cornell University]] | active = 1979–present | genre = [[Political satire|Political]]/[[news satire]], [[observational comedy]], [[insult comedy]] | subject = Mass media/news media/media criticism, American politics, American culture, current events, religion, pop culture, race relations, human sexuality | influences = | influenced = | website = {{url|billmaher.com}} }} '''William Maher''' ({{IPAc-en|m|ɑːr}}; born January 20, 1956) is an American comedian, political commentator and television host. He is known for the [[HBO]] political talk show ''[[Real Time with Bill Maher]]'' (2003–present) and the similar [[Late night television in the United States|late-night]] show called ''[[Politically Incorrect]]'' (1993-2002), originally on [[Comedy Central]] and later on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]. Maher is known for his sarcastic attitude,{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Qxa5uj95B84C&pg=PA87 |title=American Scream: The Bill Hicks Story |first=Cynthia |last=True |publisher=HarperCollins |year=2002 |isbn=9780380803774 |page=87}} political satire and sociopolitical commentary. He targets many topics including religion, politics, bureaucracy, political correctness and the mass media.{{cite news |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4792262|title=Political Satirist Bill Maher's 'New Rules'|publisher=[[NPR]]|accessdate=January 23, 2011 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110219031226/http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4792262| archivedate= February 19, 2011 | deadurl= no}} Maher supports the legalization of [[Cannabis (drug)|cannabis]] and [[same-sex marriage]]. His critical views of religion were the basis for the 2008 documentary film ''[[Religulous]]''. He is a supporter of [[animal rights]], having served on the board of [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals|PETA]] since 1997{{cite news |title=Bill Maher: 25 Things You Don't Know About Me|date=January 23, 2015|author=US Weekly Staff|work=[[Us Weekly]]|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/bill-maher-25-things-you-dont-know-about-me-2015231}} and is an advisory board member of [[Project Reason]].{{Cite news| title = Interview with Larry King, 9-28-03| url = http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0308/28/lkl.00.html| quote = Larry, I'm a PETA board member.| work=CNN}}[https://web.archive.org/web/20100608062154/http://www.project-reason.org/about/advisory_board The Reason Project]; Project Reason.org; 2011 In 2005, Maher ranked at number 38 on [[Comedy Central]]'s 100 greatest stand-up comedians of all time.{{cite web|url=http://www.comedycentral.com/tv_shows/100greatest/list.jhtml |title="Comedy Central's Top 100" |accessdate=2005-04-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050404175840/http://www.comedycentral.com/tv_shows/100greatest/list.jhtml |archivedate=April 4, 2005 |df=mdy }}. Comedy Central. April 4, 2005 He received a [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]] star on September 14, 2010.{{Cite news|title = Bill Maher gets Hollywood Walk of Fame star, September 14, 2010|url = https://www.usatoday.com/life/people/2010-09-14-maher-hollywood-star_N.htm|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=September 14, 2010}} {{TOC limit|3}} ==Early life== Maher was born in New York City. His father, William Aloysius Maher Jr., was a network news editor and radio announcer, and his mother, Julie Maher (née Berman), was a nurse.{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/32/Bill-Maher.html|title=Bill Maher Biography|publisher=Film Reference|accessdate=January 17, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080108083123/http://www.filmreference.com/film/32/Bill-Maher.html|archivedate=January 8, 2008|deadurl=no}} He was raised in his Irish-American father's Roman Catholic religion. Until his early teens, he was unaware that his mother, whose family was from Hungary,{{cite web|url=http://www.dead-frog.com/comedians/comic/bill_maher|title=Bill Maher|work=Dead-Frog|accessdate=April 10, 2013|quote= Part Hungarian part Irish...}} was Jewish.{{cite news|url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0205/24/lkl.00.html|title=Interview With Bill Maher|date=May 24, 2002|publisher=CNN|accessdate=January 17, 2008|quote= My mother is Jewish. But I never even knew I was half-Jewish until I was a teen-ager.}}{{cite web|date=November–December 2008|last=Carlin-McCall|first= Kelly|url= http://www.irishabroad.com/irishworld/irishamericamag/octnov08/features/bill-maher-octnov08.asp|title= The Real Bill|publisher=[[Irish America magazine]]|accessdate= April 23, 2010|quote= So the fact that I'm half Irish and half Jewish, they both contributed to a sense of humor.}}{{cite news|date=July 2011|last= Morgan|first= Piers|url= http://religion.blogs.cnn.com/2011/07/12/maher-on-religion/|title= Bill Maher explains his 'apatheism,' apathetic atheism|publisher= CNN|accessdate= July 12, 2011|quote=... and I was raised Catholic. I was never Jewish}} Owing to his disagreement with the Catholic Church's doctrine about birth control, Maher's father stopped taking Maher and his sister to Catholic church services when Maher was thirteen.{{cite web|url=http://media.www.diamondbackonline.com/media/storage/paper873/news/2008/10/03/Diversions/Getting.Blasphemous.In.The.Presence.Of.Bill.Maher-3467097.shtml|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081221013449/http://media.www.diamondbackonline.com/media/storage/paper873/news/2008/10/03/Diversions/Getting.Blasphemous.In.The.Presence.Of.Bill.Maher-3467097.shtml|archivedate=2008-12-21|title=Getting Blasphemous in the Presence of Bill Maher|publisher=Media.www.diamondbackonline.com|accessdate=October 18, 2010}} Maher was raised in [[River Vale, New Jersey]], and graduated from [[Pascack Hills High School]] in [[Montvale, New Jersey|Montvale]] in 1974. He then attended [[Cornell University]], where he double majored in English and history, and graduated in 1978.{{cite web|url=http://www.comcast.net/slideshow/entertainment-ivyleague/29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808123410/http://www.comcast.net/slideshow/entertainment-ivyleague/29|dead-url=yes|archive-date=August 8, 2014|title=Entertainment; Ivy League Celebrities|publisher=Comcast.net|accessdate=November 7, 2011}} Maher has said: "selling pot allowed me to get through college and make enough money to start off in comedy."[http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2013-09-05/bill-maher-how-did-i-get-here Bill Maher: How did I get here?]; Bloomberg BusinessWeek; September 5, 2013; Real Life with Bill Maher, November 7, 2014. ==Career== ===Early career=== Maher began his career as a comedian and actor. He was host of the New York City [[comedy club]] [[Catch a Rising Star (comedy clubs)|Catch a Rising Star]] in 1979. Maher began appearing on [[Johnny Carson]]'s and [[David Letterman]]'s shows in 1982.[http://projects.latimes.com/hollywood/star-walk/bill-maher/ Bill Maher - Hollywood Star Walk]; ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''; Patrick Kevin Day; September 13, 2010 He made limited television appearances including on ''[[Sara (U.S. 1985 TV series)|Sara]]'' (1985),{{cite news|work=[[The New York Times]]|title=Bill Maher Filmography|url=https://www.nytimes.com/movies/person/44630/Bill-Maher/filmography|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150620224945/http://www.nytimes.com/movies/person/44630/Bill-Maher/filmography|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2015-06-20}} ''[[Max Headroom (TV series)|Max Headroom]]'' (1987),''Science Fiction, Horror & Fantasy Film and Television Credits: Television shows''; Harris M. Lentz; McFarland Publishing, 2001; Pg. 1944 ''[[Murder, She Wrote]]'' (1989, 1990), and ''[[Charlie Hoover]]'' (1991). His feature film debut was in ''[[D.C. Cab]]'' (1983). He later appeared in ''[[Ratboy]]'' (1986), ''[[House II: The Second Story]]'' (1987), ''[[Cannibal Women in the Avocado Jungle of Death]]'' (1988), and ''[[Pizza Man]]'' (1991). ===Television career=== [[File:SethMcFarlaneBillMaherSept10.jpg|thumb|[[Seth MacFarlane]] speaking at a ceremony for Maher to receive a star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]] in September 2010]] ====''Politically Incorrect with Bill Maher''==== {{Main|Politically Incorrect}} Maher assumed the host role on ''Politically Incorrect with Bill Maher'', a late-night political talk show that ran on Comedy Central from 1993 to 1997 and on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] from 1997 to 2002. The show regularly began with a topical monologue by Maher preceding the introduction of four guests, usually a diverse group of individuals, such as show business, popular culture, political pundits, political consultants, authors, and occasionally news figures. The group would discuss topical issues selected by Maher, who also participated in the discussions.{{Cite news |url = https://www.nytimes.com/1994/02/27/arts/television-lots-of-political-humor-and-no-morton-kondracke.html?n=Top/Reference/Times%20Topics/People/M/Maher,%20Bill |title = TELEVISION; Lots of Political Humor, and No Morton Kondracke|date = February 27, 1994 |newspaper = The New York Times | first=Bill| last=Carter |accessdate = August 9, 2010}} [[Jerry Seinfeld]], a regular guest on the show, stated that ''Politically Incorrect'' reminded him of talk shows from the 1950s and '60s "when guests interacted with each other as much as with the host". ''Politically Incorrect'' won an array of awards, including an [[Emmy Award]] for Outstanding Technical Direction, two [[CableACE]] awards for Best Talk Show Series, and a [[Genesis Award]] for Best Television Talk Show. Maher earned numerous award nominations for his producing, writing, and hosting of ''Politically Incorrect'', including ten [[Emmy]] nominations, two [[TV Guide]] nominations, and two [[Writers Guild of America|Writers Guild]] nominations. ABC decided against renewing Maher's contract for ''Politically Incorrect'' in 2002, after he made a controversial on-air remark six days after the [[September 11 attacks]].{{cite web|url=http://thebigstory.org/ov/ov-politicallyincorrect.html |title=The Big Story: Politically Incorrect |accessdate=June 19, 2007 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070713120522/http://thebigstory.org/ov/ov-politicallyincorrect.html| archivedate= July 13, 2007 | deadurl= no}} He agreed with his guest, conservative [[pundit (expert)|pundit]] [[Dinesh D'Souza]], that the 9/11 terrorists did not act in a cowardly manner (in rebuttal to [[George W. Bush|President Bush]]'s statement calling them cowards). Maher said, "We have been the cowards. Lobbing cruise missiles from 2,000 miles away. That's cowardly. Staying in the airplane when it hits the building. Say what you want about it. Not cowardly. You're right." Maher later clarified that his comment was not anti-military in any way whatsoever, referencing his well-documented longstanding support for the American military.{{Cite book|last=Goldberg |first=Danny |authorlink= |title=It's a Free Country: Personal Freedom in America After September 11 |publisher=RDV Books |year=2002 |page=77 |isbn=0-9719206-0-5}}{{Cite news |last=Garofoli |first=Joe |title=Talk host's towering rant: S.F. not worth saving |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2005/11/11/MNGFMFMNV41.DTL |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |accessdate=October 9, 2007 |postscript= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071102175526/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=%2Fc%2Fa%2F2005%2F11%2F11%2FMNGFMFMNV41.DTL |archivedate=November 2, 2007 |deadurl=no |df=mdy-all }} After receiving complaints, [[FedEx]] and [[Sears|Sears Roebuck]] pulled their advertisements from the show, costing the show significant revenue.{{Cite news |last=Navasky |first=Victor |title=Profiles in Cowardice |url=http://www.thenation.com/doc/20011105/navasky |newspaper=[[The Nation]] |accessdate=October 9, 2007 |postscript= |archiveurl=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20090630183528/http%3A//www%2Ethenation%2Ecom/doc/20011105/navasky |archivedate=June 30, 2009 |deadurl=no |df=mdy-all }}{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZjnUyVhccr4C&pg=PA389 |title=Entertainment and Society: Influences, Impacts, and Innovations |last=Sayre |first=Shay |last2=King |first2=Cynthia |publisher=Taylor & Francis |year=2010 |edition=2 |isbn=9780203882931 |accessdate=2013-04-19}} Maher's remarks after 9/11 were not the first time he had sparked controversy on ''Politically Incorrect''. In the same year, he expressed his deep regrets and apologized after being widely criticized for comparing his dogs to retarded children.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/01/18/us/tv-host-s-words-draw-criticism-and-apology.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|title=TV Host's Words Draw Criticism and Apology|date=January 18, 2001|accessdate=April 1, 2010}} The show was canceled on June 16, 2002, and the [[Sinclair Broadcast Group]] had dropped the show from its [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]-[[Network affiliate|affiliated]] stations months prior. On June 22, 2002, just six days after the cancellation of ''Politically Incorrect'', Maher received the Los Angeles Press Club president's award (for "championing free speech"). Maher was on the board of judges for the 2002 [[PEN/Newman's Own First Amendment Award]].Siems, Larry (April 11, 2002). [http://www.pen.org/press-release/2002/04/11/vanessa-leggett-receive-2002-pennewmans-own-first-amendment-award "Vanessa Leggett to receive 2002 PEN/Newman's Own First Amendment Award"], Pen American Center; accessed September 30, 2018. ====''Real Time with Bill Maher''==== {{Main|Real Time with Bill Maher}} In 2003, Maher became the host, co-producer, and co-writer of ''Real Time with Bill Maher'', a weekly hour-long political comedy talk show on the cable television network [[HBO]]. In 2016, HBO renewed ''Real Time'' through 2018, for its 15th and 16th seasons.{{cite news|last1=Prudom|first1=Laura|title=‘Real Time With Bill Maher’ Renewed Through 2018|url=https://variety.com/2016/tv/news/real-time-with-bill-maher-renewed-season-15-16-1201827123/|accessdate=August 1, 2016|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=30 July 2016}} During an interview, Maher told [[Terry Gross]] (on NPR's ''[[Fresh Air]]'') that he much prefers having serious and well-informed guests on his program, as opposed to the random celebrities that fleshed out his roundtable discussions on ''Politically Incorrect''.{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4490632|work=NPR|title=Bill Maher: Four More Years|date=February 8, 2005|accessdate=August 9, 2010}} As with his previous show, ''Politically Incorrect'', Maher begins ''Real Time'' with a comic opening monologue based upon current events and other topical issues. He proceeds to a one-on-one interview with a guest, either in-studio or via satellite. Following the interview, Maher sits with two or three panelists, usually consisting of [[pundit (expert)|pundits]], authors, activists, actors, politicians, and journalists, for a discussion of the week's events. ''Real Time'' has earned widespread praise. It has been nominated for more than ten Primetime [[Emmy Awards]] and six [[Writers Guild of America|Writer's Guild]] awards. In 2007, Maher and his co-producers were awarded the Television Producer of the Year Award in Variety Television by the Producers Guild of America.[http://www.producersguild.org/?page=PGA_Award_19902010&hhSearchTerms=PGA+and+Award+and+Winners+and+1990-2010 Producers Guild of America Awards – Winners 1990-2010]; PGA.org; May 29, 2012 Maher holds the record for the most Emmy nominations without a win, having been nominated on 22 occasions and not winning once. Eleven of the nominations were for ''Politically Incorrect'', while nine were for ''Real Time''. The other two were nominations for two of his HBO comedy specials: ''[[I'm Swiss]]'' and ''[[Bill Maher: The Decider]]''.{{Cite news| url=http://goldderby.latimes.com/awards_goldderby/2009/07/will-emmys-biggest-loser-bill-maher-ever-win.html | work=Los Angeles Times | title=Gold Derby | date=July 20, 2009}} =====Notable responses to ''Real Time'' episodes===== In late May 2005, Alabama Congressman [[Spencer Bachus]] sent a letter to [[Time Warner]]'s board of directors requesting ''Real Time'' be canceled after remarks Maher made after noting the military had missed its recruiting goals by 42 percent. Bachus said he felt the comments were demeaning to the military and treasonous. Maher stated his highest regard and support for the troops and asked why the congressman criticized him instead of doing something about the recruitment problem.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,157435,00.html |title=Bill Maher's Remark About Army 'Borders on Treason,' Lawmaker Says – Celebrity Gossip |publisher=FOX News |date=May 23, 2005 |accessdate=October 18, 2010}} On September 17, 2010, Maher aired a clip of Delaware [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] Senatorial candidate [[Christine O'Donnell]] from the October 29, 1999 episode of his old show ''Politically Incorrect'' on his current show ''Real Time with Bill Maher'',{{cite news|last=McGreal|first=Chris|title=Christine O'Donnell: I dabbled in witchcraft|date=September 20, 2010|work=The Guardian|location=London|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/sep/20/christine-o-donnell-dabbled-witchcraft|accessdate=September 20, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100922011030/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/sep/20/christine-o-donnell-dabbled-witchcraft| archivedate= September 22, 2010|deadurl=no}}{{cite news |url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/entertainment/bs-ae-arts-story-1119-20101118,0,6769640.story|title=Bill Maher celebrates the art of standup|first=Michael|last=Sragow |newspaper=The Baltimore Sun}} where she mentioned that she had "dabbled in witchcraft". This was one of the most notable of numerous controversial statements by O'Donnell that made her the most covered candidate in the 2010 mid-term election cycle.[http://www.journalism.org/numbers_report/midterms’_media_mainstays The Midterms' Media Mainstays | Project for Excellence in Journalism (PEJ)]{{cite news|url=http://watching-tv.ew.com/2010/09/19/christine-odonnell-witchcraft-bill-maher|title=Christine O'Donnell, witchcraft, and Bill Maher: TV and politics put a hex on common sense|author=Ken Tucker|work=Entertainment Weekly}} In February 2017, Maher invited [[Milo Yiannopoulos]] to be interviewed on ''Real Time.'' Yiannopoulos accepted, despite protests from some commentators and fans. The appearance on Maher's show harmed Yannopoulos's career due to comments in the interview in which he seemed to express sympathy toward perpetrators of child sexual abuse. In the days following the interview, Yiannopoulos had his invitation to speak before the 2017 [[Conservative Political Action Conference]], as well as a book deal with [[Simon & Schuster]], cancelled. Yiannopoulos subsequently resigned as an editor at [[Breitbart News]]. When asked whether Yiannopoulos's interview on his show was among the causes of his resignation, Maher concurred, saying, "As I say, sunlight is the best disinfectant. You're welcome."{{cite news|first=Dave|last=Itzkoff|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/22/arts/television/bill-maher-milo-yiannopoulos-interview.html|title=Bill Maher, Faulted for Booking Milo Yiannopoulos, Takes Credit for His Fall|date=February 22, 2017|accessdate=February 22, 2017}} Later in June 2017, Maher came under criticism for saying "I'm a [[house nigger]]" on Real Time with calls being made by people to HBO to fire him.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/jun/03/bill-maher-hbo-real-time-ben-sasse|title=Bill Maher sorry for use of N-word as HBO calls it 'inexcusable and tasteless'|first=Martin|last=Pengelly|date=June 3, 2017|publisher=The Guardian}} Following the episode, HBO sent a statement to media outlets, calling Maher's remarks "inexcusable and tasteless" and said the cable network will remove that segment from future airings of the show.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/arts-and-entertainment/wp/2017/06/03/bill-maher-faces-calls-for-firing-after-using-the-n-word-on-his-hbo-show/|title=Bill Maher says he is 'very sorry' for using a racial slur on his HBO show|first1=Kristine|last1=Phillips|first2=Kristine|last2=Phillips|date=June 3, 2017|publisher=washingtonpost.com}} Maher also issued a statement apologizing for the remarks. ===Political commentator=== Maher is a frequent commentator on various cable news networks, including [[CNN]], [[MSNBC]], [[Fox News]], and [[HLN (TV channel)|HLN]]. Maher has regularly appeared on CNN's ''[[The Situation Room with Wolf Blitzer]]''{{cite news |url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/Zach-Galifianakis-Joint-1024995.aspx|title=Bill Maher: Zach Galifianakis Did Not Light Up a Real Joint|author=Robyn Ross |work=TV Guide}} and has also been a frequent guest on [[MSNBC]]'s ''[[Hardball with Chris Matthews]]'',{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/11366025/ns/msnbc_tv-hardball_with_chris_matthews|title=Bill Maher plays Hardball|publisher=MSN}} ''[[The Rachel Maddow Show (TV series)|The Rachel Maddow Show]]'',{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/huff-tv/arianna-hosts-the-irachel_b_144514.html|title=Arianna Hosts The Rachel Maddow Show with Guests Bill Maher, Lawrence O'Donnell, Nate Silver, Cory Booker and Google's Eric Schmidt|publisher=The Huffington Post|date=December 18, 2008}} and ''[[Countdown with Keith Olbermann]]''.{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/3036677/#40225161|title=Maher on Countdown with Keith Olbermann (video)|publisher=MSNBC|date=January 21, 2011|accessdate=November 7, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111106044244/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/3036677|archivedate=November 6, 2011}} Maher has also appeared as a guest on [[HLN (TV channel)|HLN]]'s ''[[The Joy Behar Show]]''.{{cite news|url=http://joybehar.blogs.cnn.com/2010/09/28/bill-maher-spends-some-real-time-with-joy|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101002121611/http://joybehar.blogs.cnn.com/2010/09/28/bill-maher-spends-some-real-time-with-joy|archivedate=2010-10-02|title=Bill Maher spends some real time with Joy|publisher=CNN}} He wrote the foreword for the 2002 book, ''Spin This!: All the Ways We Don't Tell the Truth'' by show host [[Bill Press]].''Spin This!: All the Ways We Don't Tell the Truth''; Bill Press; Simon & Schuster; 2002; Pg. xi Maher hosted the January 13, 2006 edition of ''[[Larry King Live]]'', on which he was a frequent guest. Maher appeared as a special guest on the June 29, 2010 edition of the show, on which CNN [[anchor]] [[Larry King]] announced his retirement.{{Cite news|url=http://www.mediaite.com/tv/bill-maher-helps-larry-king-say-goodbye/ | publisher=Mediaite|title=Bill Maher helps Larry King say goodbye|accessdate=August 9, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100706044557/http://www.mediaite.com/tv/bill-maher-helps-larry-king-say-goodbye|archivedate= July 6, 2010|deadurl=no}} Maher co-emceed the final show of ''[[Larry King Live]]'' on December 16, 2010 with [[Ryan Seacrest]].{{cite news|last=Rowe|first=Douglas J.|url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/Larry-King-Ends-1026885.aspx|title=Surrounded by Famous Fans, Larry King Ends His 25-Year Run on CNN|work=TV Guide|date=December 16, 2010|accessdate=November 7, 2011}} ===Other work=== In 2004 Maher appeared on stage as Satan in [[The Steve Allen Theater]] production of "Hollywood Hell House", a spoof of the Christian-run [[hell house]]s. The show was a faithful reproduction of an evangelistic scare-experience written by Reverend Keenan Roberts to terrify teenagers into declaring themselves Christians. "Our faith is that putting this up as itself, it will hoist itself on its own petard, that it's comical just as it is," explained producer Maggie Rowe. The show featured a rotating cast of over 160 celebrities, including [[Andy Richter]] (Jesus), [[Richard Belzer]], [[Dave Thomas (actor)|Dave Thomas]], [[Traci Lords]], [[Craig Bierko]], [[Sarah Silverman]], and [[Julia Sweeney]].{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2004/aug/22/entertainment/ca-artsnotes22.3|title=Scared straight to Hollywood|first=Lynne|last=Heffley|date=August 22, 2004|publisher=|via=LA Times}} Maher and director [[Larry Charles]] teamed up to make the movie ''[[Religulous]]'', described by trade publication ''Variety'' as a documentary "that spoofs religious extremism across the world". It was released on October 3, 2008.Demara, Bruce. (September 10, 2007.) [https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/article/254761 "Maher preaches to the TIFF choir"]. ''[[The Toronto Star]]''. Retrieved on October 9, 2007.Jaafar, Ali; Hayes, Dade (September 10, 2007.) [https://variety.com/2007/film/news/toronto-festival-wary-of-serious-films-1117971744/ "Toronto festival wary of serious films: 'Religulous' finds following at film fest"]. ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]''. Retrieved on October 9, 2007. In 2013 Maher became one of the [[Executive producer#Television|executive producers]] for the HBO newsmagazine series ''[[Vice (TV series)|Vice]]''.Nededog, Jehtro (May 10, 2012). [http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/hbo-bill-maher-vice-newsmagazine-show-323023 "HBO, Bill Maher Team With Vice for Newsmagazine"]. ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]''.Hinckley, David (April 5, 2013). [http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv-movies/tv-review-vice-hbo-article-1.1307802 "TV review: 'Vice' on HBO"]. ''[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]''. Also in 2013, Maher appeared on ''[[The Tonight Show with Jay Leno]]'' and offered to pay $5 million to a charity if [[Donald Trump]] would produce his [[birth certificate]] to prove that Trump's mother had not mated with an [[orangutan]]. Maher said this reportedly in response to Trump having previously challenged President [[Barack Obama]] to produce his birth certificate, and having offered $5 million payable to a charity of Obama's choice if Obama would produce his college applications, transcripts, and passport records.{{cite news|url=http://nydailynews.com/news/election-2012/trump-puts-kibosh-5m-offer-obama-article-1.1195668|title=Trump puts kibosh on $5M offer to Obama|work=Daily News|location=New York|first=Kristen A.|last=Lee|date=November 1, 2012|accessdate=August 19, 2015}} In response to Maher's offer, Trump produced his birth certificate, and then [[Legal affairs of Donald Trump|Trump launched a lawsuit]] after Maher was not forthcoming, claiming that Maher's $5 million offer was legally binding. "I don't think he was joking", Trump said. "He said it with venom."{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/frederickallen/2013/02/06/donald-trump-sues-bill-maher-for-calling-him-the-son-of-an-orangutan|title=Donald Trump Sues Bill Maher for Calling Him the Son of an Orangutan|work=Forbes|date=February 6, 2013|accessdate=August 18, 2015|first=Michael E.|last=Allen}} Trump withdrew his lawsuit against the comedian after eight weeks.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSBRE9310PL20130402|title=Trump withdraws 'orangutan' lawsuit against comic Bill Maher|agency=Reuters|date=April 3, 2013|accessdate=August 4, 2015|first=Joseph|last=Ax}} On May 13, 2016, Maher and his friend [[Michael Moore]] announced on YouTube that they are going to make a movie called "The Kings of Atheism".{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rqqeRL8qS-4|title=Real Time with Bill Maher: Overtime – May 13, 2016 (HBO)|date=May 13, 2016}} ==Views and beliefs== ===Politics=== [[File:Bill Maher and Ingrid Newkirk by David Shankbone.jpg|thumb|Maher and [[Ingrid Newkirk]], founder of [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals|PETA]]. Maher is on the board of directors of the animal rights group.]] Maher eschews political labels, referring to himself as "practical".{{cite web|last=Martel|first=Frances|url=http://www.mediaite.com/tv/bill-maher-to-piers-morgan-palin-can-absolutely-win-in-2012-but-hed-vote-for-bachmann|title=Bill Maher To Piers Morgan: I Hope Sarah Palin And Michele Bachmann 'Split the MILF Vote'|publisher=Mediaite|date=July 11, 2011|accessdate=November 7, 2011}} In the past, he has described himself as a [[Libertarianism|libertarian]], and has also referred to himself "as a progressive, as a sane person".Rutenberg, Jim. (October 8, 2001.) [https://www.nytimes.com/2001/10/08/business/bill-maher-still-secure-in-abc-slot-at-least-now.html "Bill Maher still secure in ABC slot, at least now"]. ''The New York Times''.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/video/?/video/bestoftv/2011/06/14/exp.ac.maher.part1.debate.cnn|title=Maher slams 2012 GOP presidential field (video)|publisher=CNN|date=July 16, 2010}} He has referred to himself as a "9/11 liberal", noting that his formerly liberal view of [[Islam]] changed as a result of the attacks on [[September 11 attacks|September 11, 2001]], and he differentiates himself from [[Modern liberalism in the United States|liberals]] of the opinion that all religions are alike.Dyess-Nugent, Phil; Kaiser, Rowan; O'Neal, Sean; Sims, David (September 11, 2013) [http://www.avclub.com/articles/never-forgot-9-entertainers-who-were-changed-by-91,102730/ "Never forgot: 9 entertainers who were changed by 9/11"]. ''[[The A.V. Club]]''. Maher favors ending [[corporate welfare]] and federal funding of [[Non-profit organization|non-profits]] as well as the legalization of gambling, prostitution, and cannabis. Maher is a member of the advisory boards for both the [[National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws|NORML]] and [[Marijuana Policy Project]], organizations that support regulated [[Legality of cannabis|legalization of cannabis]],{{cite news|url=http://norml.org/advisory-board|work=[[National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws]]|title=NORML Advisory Board|accessdate=March 22, 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://www.mpp.org/vip/|work=[[Marijuana Policy Project]]|title=MPP Advisory Board|accessdate=March 22, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/66ADLLlLM?url=http://www.mpp.org/vip/|archivedate=March 14, 2012}} and has been called "one of the brightest torches for sensible marijuana policy" and "a contemporary cannabis statesman".{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/the-/weed-time-with-bill-maher_b_5128776.html|title=Weed Time With Bill Maher|work=The Huffington Post|date=2014-04-11|accessdate=2015-07-01}} Maher describes himself as an environmentalist, and he has spoken in favor of the [[Kyoto treaty]] on [[global warming]] on his show ''Real Time''. He often criticizes industry figures involved in environmental pollution.Halem, Dann. (August 1, 2001.) [http://archive.salon.com/ent/tv/feature/2001/08/01/maher/index1.html "Is Bill Maher a libertarian?"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051130125435/http://archive.salon.com/ent/tv/feature/2001/08/01/maher/index1.html |date=November 30, 2005 }}, ''Salon'' (news website). Retrieved on October 12, 2007. He is a board member of [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals]]. The comedian has noted the paradox of people claiming they distrusted "elite" politicians while at the same time wanting elite doctors to treat them and elite lawyers to represent them in court.[http://www.salon.com/news/opinion/feature/2007/04/13/pat_robertson "Say it loud: I'm elite and proud!"] Salon; April 13, 2007 Maher supports the death penalty.[http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0512/15/lkl.01.html Larry King Live – Transcript]; CNN; December 15, 2005 Since the 9/11 attacks, he has endorsed certain uses of profiling at airports, saying that "Places like Israel, where they have faced terrorism for a long time, of course understand that profiling is part of all detective work. It's part of all police work. If they stop calling it profiling and start calling it high-intelligence screening or something, people would go, it's about time."(2002-12-16 broadcast.) [http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0212/16/ltm.15.html "CNN American Morning with Paula Zahn: Talk with Bill Maher" (Transcript) (Caveat: "This is a rush transcript.")]; retrieved on October 12, 2007. He opposed the [[Iraq War]] from the beginning, and has summarized his opinion by saying that the United States and the world have had to pay too high a price for the war. He is skeptical of Iraq surviving without civil war.{{cite web|last=Modell|first=Josh|url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/bill-maher,14307|title=Bill Maher | Film | Interview|publisher=''The A.V. Club''|accessdate=October 18, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100914144115/http://www.avclub.com/articles/bill-maher%2C14307|archivedate=September 14, 2010|deadurl=no}} In the [[United States presidential election, 2008|2008 U.S. presidential election]], Maher announced his support for U.S. Senator [[Barack Obama]] (D-IL).{{cite web|url=http://www.truthdig.com/eartotheground/item/20080204_down_to_the_wire|title=Ear to the Ground – Down to the Wire|publisher=Truthdig|accessdate=October 18, 2010}} Although Maher welcomed Obama's electoral victory, he subjected him to criticism after he took office for not acting more boldly on health care reform and other progressive issues.{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/06/15/bill-maher-tells-olberman_n_215964.html|work=Huffington Post|title=Bill Maher Tells Olbermann Why He's Criticizing Obama|date=June 15, 2009|first=Marcus|last=Baram |accessdate=February 14, 2011}} [[File:Bill Maher and Mark Warner.jpg|thumb|Maher with Senator [[Mark Warner]] ([[Democratic Party (United States)|D]]-[[Virginia|VA]])]] On February 23, 2012, after his 'Crazy Stupid Politics' special streamed on Yahoo! Screen, Maher announced that he was contributing $1 million to Priorities USA, the Obama SuperPAC.{{cite web|url=http://screen.yahoo.com/crazystupidpolitics|archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20120224193941/http://screen.yahoo.com/crazystupidpolitics|dead-url=yes|archive-date=February 24, 2012|title=CrazyStupidPolitics: Bill Maher Live on Yahoo! Screen|publisher=Screen.yahoo.com|date=2011-04-20}}{{cite tweet|user=billmaher|number=172927275690508288|date=February 23, 2012|title= Tweet by Bill Maher}} On the [[Israeli–Palestinian conflict]], Maher says he is "more on the side of the Israelis" and doesn't consider both sides equally guilty. He acknowledges that "Palestinians do have gripes", and he has been critical of U.S. financial aid to Israel, saying "they don't need our money, they can handle it themselves." Maher also notes that most Israelis would prefer a two-state solution and oppose the hard-line stance of their Israeli government, which he describes as having been taken over by their version of the Tea Party. However, Maher has defended Israel's military actions against Palestinian militants amid criticism over civilian deaths and disproportionate casualty count between Israelis and Palestinians during the [[2014 Israel–Gaza conflict|2014 Gaza war]]. He argues that Israel is still showing restraint, and he finds it ironic that the same people who were incredulous over how the Jews in World War II were led "to their slaughter", can't understand why they are defending themselves now.[http://www.mediaite.com/tv/%E2%80%98people-die-in-wars%E2%80%99-maher-and-guests-battle-over-gaza-civilian-deaths/ Bill Maher Defends Israel Again: 'People Die in Wars], Mediaite, August 1, 2014 Maher is a gun owner, and explained in his February 12, 2013 appearance on the late night TV talk show ''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]'' that he owns guns for personal home protection. However, he does not identify himself as a "proud" gun owner, commenting that being a proud gun owner is akin to "saying I'm a 'proud remote control owner'". Maher has stated that statistics showing that gun owners are more likely to harm a member of their household are caused by irresponsible gun owners, and believes that tragedies such as school shootings will not lead to fundamental change in gun laws because both [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrats]] and [[Republican Party (United States)|Republicans]] favor guns.{{cite episode|title=The Walls Have Ears, and Other Side Effects of This Medication|series=[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]|season=3|number=45|airdate=February 12, 2013|network=[[TBS (U.S. TV channel)|TBS]]}} On June 7, 2013, Bill Maher expressed on his show limited support for the [[National Security Agency|NSA's]] [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]] intelligence data collection from private phone calls and the Internet, saying that the threat of terrorists obtaining and using nuclear weapons was the tipping point for him. While he stated that he trusted the Obama administration to employ the program responsibly, he described the NSA's access to private data as a "slippery slope", and worried about whether other politicians would be as responsible.{{cite web|author=Garcia, Arturo|url=http://www.rawstory.com/rs/2013/06/07/maher-defends-nsa-data-searches-its-not-because-im-brave-but-because-im-scared|title=Maher defends NSA data searches: It's not because I'm brave, but because I'm scared|publisher=[[The Raw Story]]|date=June 7, 2013}} In the leadup to the 2014 midterm elections, Maher conducted a "Flip a District" contest on his HBO show. His audience was asked to select one "terrible, entrenched" member of Congress in a close election race—"the loserest loser of all"—to remove from office. Maher aimed to help oust that representative by shining a "national spotlight" on the politician during segments of his show and stand-up comedy appearances in that member's district during the Fall election.[https://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/31/arts/television/maher-wants-his-show-to-decide-a-house-race.html?partner=rss&emc=rss&smid=tw-thecaucus&_r=1 Maher Wants His Show to Decide a House Race]; New York Times; Bill Carter; January 30, 2014.[http://www.real-time-with-bill-maher-blog.com/index/2014/1/31/test Flip a District]; Real Time with Bill Maher; June 3, 2014. Maher endorsed [[Maine Question 1, 2014|a 2014 Maine referendum]] to ban the use of bait, traps, and dogs to hunt bears in Maine. He specifically criticized the use of bait, referring to its use as "nothing but an execution".{{cite news|work=[[Bangor Daily News]]|url=http://stateandcapitol.bangordailynews.com/2014/09/15/famous-talk-show-host-bill-maher-endorses-referendum-to-ban-bear-baiting|title=Famous talk show host Bill Maher endorses referendum to ban bear baiting|date=September 15, 2014|accessdate=September 15, 2014}} In the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 U.S. presidential election]], Maher initially endorsed Senator [[Bernie Sanders]] on February 5, 2016. Maher later announced his support for [[Hillary Clinton]] after Sanders had lost the Democratic Party primary elections."[http://observer.com/2016/07/bill-maher-im-with-her-or-im-with-stupid/ Bill Maher: 'I'm With Her' or 'I'm With Stupid']". ''[[The Observer]]'', July 29, 2016. In October 2016, Maher criticized [[WikiLeaks]] founder [[Julian Assange]] for publishing [[2016 Democratic National Committee email leak|leaks from the DNC's emails]], saying: "I really feel like he's lost his way a little, and he hates Hillary.""[http://www.thedailybeast.com/bill-maher-and-michael-moore-turn-on-julian-assange-i-feel-like-hes-drifted Bill Maher and Michael Moore Turn on Julian Assange: 'I Feel Like He's Drifted']", ''[[The Daily Beast]]'', October 29, 2016. ===Religion=== {{See also|Religulous}} Maher is highly [[Criticism of religion|critical of all religion]] and views it as highly destructive. He has been described, or self-identified, variously as an agnostic, [[Atheism|atheist]], and [[Apatheism|apatheist]], while objecting to having his views defined by a single label. In his 2008 feature film ''[[Religulous]]'', he refers to himself as agnostic.Holden, Stephen (September 30, 2008). [https://movies.nytimes.com/2008/10/01/movies/01reli.html "Believers, Skeptics and a Pool of Sitting Ducks"], ''The New York Times'' He has rejected being grouped with explicit atheists, saying in 2002, "I'm not an atheist. There's a really big difference between an atheist and someone who just doesn't believe in religion. Religion to me is a bureaucracy between man and God that I don't need, but I'm not an atheist, no."Thompson, Stephen (October 9, 2002). [http://www.avclub.com/articles/is-there-a-god,1413/ "Is There a God?"]. ''[[The A.V. Club]]''. Maher has also occasionally referred to himself as an apatheist, saying in 2011 "I don't know what happens when you die, and I don't care." When discussing his apatheism and his views on the existence of God, he said on a scale from 1 to 7 (7 being "absolutely certain there is no god"), he was only at 6.9, like [[Richard Dawkins]], "because we just don't know ... but we just don't think about it." He added, "There's atheist and there's agnostic, and I'm okay with us not splitting the difference on those; if you are just not a super-religious person, you are on my team."[http://religion.blogs.cnn.com/2011/07/12/maher-on-religion "Bill Maher explains his 'apatheism,' apathetic atheism"]. [[CNN]] Belief Blogs, July 12, 2011. Several months later on a 2012 episode of his HBO show, Maher declared that "idiots must stop claiming that atheism is a religion. [...] believe it or not, I don't really enjoy talking about religion all the time. In fact, not only is atheism not a religion, it's not even my hobby, and that's the best thing about being an atheist. It requires so little of your time."[http://www.hbo.com/real-time-with-bill-maher/episodes/0/236-episode/article/new-rules.html HBO: Real Time with Bill Maher; Episode 236 – New Rules]; Home Box Office; February 3, 2012 He has reiterated his stance during other interviews, rejecting both the certitude of the existence, as well as the certitude of nonexistence of deities, concluding, "I'm saying that doubt is the only appropriate response for human beings."[http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/film/article6010432.ece "Bill Maher: The God Botherer"]. ''[[The Sunday Times]]'' April 1, 2009. While critical of all organized religions, saying "they're all stupid and dangerous", Maher says all religions are not alike, and has drawn comparisons and contrasts between them.[http://www.rawstory.com/2015/01/bill-maher-on-paris-massacre-there-are-no-great-religions-theyre-all-stupid-and-dangerous/ Bill Maher on Paris massacre: 'There are no great religions — they’re all stupid and dangerous']; ''Raw Story''; January 8, 2015Schwarwtz, Ian (September 23, 2012). [http://www.realclearpolitics.com/video/2012/09/23/bill_maher_on_islam_all_religions_are_not_alike.html "Bill Maher On Islam: 'All Religions Are Not Alike'"]. [[RealClearPolitics]]. He has said, "By any standard, [[Mormonism]] is more ridiculous than any other religion."{{cite news|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/print/700213557/Group-lists-Top-Ten-Anti-Mormon-Statements-of-2011.html|title=Group lists Top Ten Anti-Mormon Statements of 2011|date=January 8, 2012|work=[[Deseret News]]|first=Joseph|last=Walker}} He has referred to tenets of Judaism as "insane" and "funny", and has said Buddhism "includes crazy whack shit that doesn't exist, that somebody made up, like reincarnation".Berrin, Danielle (November 29, 2012). [http://www.jewishjournal.com/hollywoodjew/item/bill_maher_on_israel_uncut_and_uncensored "Bill Maher on Israel, uncut and uncensored"], ''[[The Jewish Journal of Greater Los Angeles]]''. He has described Christianity and Islam as more "warlike", and has asserted that, like historic Christianity, present-day Islam needs to undergo its own [[reformation]] and [[Age of Enlightenment|enlightenment]].{{cite news|last1=Kohn|first1=Sally|title=Petition All You Want, Bill Maher Will Speak at Berkeley|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/news/politics/2014/12/bill-maher-interview-islam-berkeley|work=Vanity Fair|date=December 2014|accessdate=April 13, 2015}} In defense of his criticism of Islam, Sharia law and Muslim culture, Maher says he is "... someone who believes in the values that Western people believe in that a lot of the Muslim world does not. Like separation of church and state. Like equality of the sexes. Like respect for minorities, free elections, free speech, freedom to gather. These things are not just different from cultures that don't have them.... It's better ... I would like to keep those values here."{{cite web|url=http://www.mediaite.com/tv/bill-maher-stands-by-mohammed-remarks-i-dont-need-to-apologize-for-being-a-proud-westerner|title=Bill Maher Stands By Mohammed Remarks: 'I Don't Need To Apologize For Being A Proud Westerner'|publisher=Mediaite|date=November 1, 2010|accessdate=March 13, 2011}} Citing studies and poll results by [[Pew Research Center]], the [[World Economic Forum]] and others, Maher says the human rights violations and "illiberal ideas" found in Islam are not extremist views held by a small minority, but are supported by a majority of citizens in Muslim countries. Maher has criticized liberals as hypocritical for defending these core liberal values and ideals only at home, while not condemning the oppression of these values and groups in Muslim culture.{{cite news|last1=Sasson|first1=Eric|title=Yes, Bill Maher Is Boorish. But We Shouldn't Be Afraid to Criticize Islam|url=https://newrepublic.com/article/119762/bill-maher-ben-affleck-islam-debate-we-can-do-better|work=The New Republic|date=9 October 2014 }} Regarding the more recent publicity generated by his stance in the ongoing debate, Maher says he thinks people are finally paying closer attention to a conversation that they need to have. "I'm just shining a light on the reality of the situation. I don't even understand why this is so controversial." Maher received the 2009 [[Richard Dawkins Award]] from [[Atheist Alliance International]].Timonen, Josh (September 28, 2009). [http://old.richarddawkins.net/articles/4388 "A note about the 'Richard Dawkins Award' being presented to Bill Maher this weekend"]. [[The Richard Dawkins Foundation]]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130623001937/http://old.richarddawkins.net/articles/4388 |date=June 23, 2013 }} He is an advisory board member of author [[Sam Harris (author)|Sam Harris]]'s [[Project Reason]], a foundation that promotes scientific knowledge and secular values within society.{{citation needed|date=September 2018}} ===Health care=== Maher has stated that the [[American Medical Association]] is a powerful lobbying group and one of the primary reasons why the United States had failed to enact health care reform.(2009-06-15). {{YouTube|wJ2L1aQy-io|Keith Olbermann: Bill Maher Talks About Taking On Obama}}.{{Dead link|date=July 2011}} Countdown With Keith Olbermann. Retrieved June 30, 2009.[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/31387052/ns/msnbc_tv-countdown_with_keith_olbermann/ Countdown With Keith Olbermann]; MSNBC; June 15, 2009 On the topic of getting [[Health care reform in the United States|health care reform]] legislation passed, Maher stated that Obama should forget about trying to get 60 votes for it, "he only needs 51." "Forget getting the sixty votes or sixty percent—sixty percent of people don't believe in evolution in this country—he just needs to drag them to it, like I said, they're stupid; get health care done, with or without them."{{cite AV Media|url=http://www.tonightshowwithconanobrien.com/video/clips/bill-maher-pt2-082409/1149697|title=Bill Maher Part 2|work=The Tonight Show|accessdate=October 18, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090830072642/http://www.tonightshowwithconanobrien.com/video/clips/bill-maher-pt2-082409/1149697|archivedate=August 30, 2009}} On [[Fox News Channel|Fox News]] in a televised debate with [[Bill O'Reilly (political commentator)|Bill O'Reilly]], Maher said that "if Jesus was in charge of the country we'd probably have health care for everybody."{{cite web|url=http://www.mediaite.com/tv/bill-maher-on-the-factor-part-ii-the-two-bills-clash-on-religion|title=Bill Maher On ''The Factor'', Part II: The Two Bills Clash On Religion|date=September 30, 2010|last=Davis|first=Glenn|publisher=Mediaite|accessdate=February 14, 2013}} Maher has expressed the view that a lot of illness is the result of poor diet and lack of exercise, and that medicine is often not the most appropriate way of addressing illness. In an episode of his show about the 2008 presidential candidates' health plans, Maher stated that poor nutrition is a primary cause of illness, and that "the answer isn't another pill."''Real Time with Bill Maher''; [https://web.archive.org/web/20071015061830/http://hbo.com/billmaher/new_rules/20070928.html September 28, 2007]; HBO He also has said: "If you believe you need to take all the pills the pharmaceutical industry says you do, then you're already on drugs!"{{cite web|url=http://www.winhs.org|publisher=WINHS, World Institute of Natural Health Sciences|title=Home|accessdate=2012-02-24}} He has expressed his distaste for the [[Pharmaceutical drug|pharmaceutical]] and health care industries in general, on the grounds that they make their money out of treating people who are made sick by consuming [[junk food|unhealthy food]] that corporations urge upon the public. He maintains that mass consumption of [[high-fructose corn syrup]] is a contributor to the rise in frequency of [[obesity in the United States]].[http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0409/13/lkl.00.html Larry King Live – Interview With Bill Maher]; CNN; September 13, 2004 In a discussion with [[Michael Moore]] about the film ''[[Sicko]]'', Maher said, "The human body is pretty amazing; it doesn't get sick, usually, for no reason. I mean, there's some genetic stuff that can get to you, but, basically, people are sick in this country because they're poisoned. The environment is a poisoning factor, but also, we gotta say, they poison themselves. They eat shit. People eat shit, and that's, to my way of thinking, about 90 percent of why people are sick, is because they eat shit."Kerry Trueman, [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/kerry-trueman/maher-and-moore-chew-out-_b_50004.html Maher and Moore Chew (Out) the Fat]; ''The Huffington Post''; May 30, 2007. [[Tara Parker-Pope]] and former Senator (R-TN) Dr. [[Bill Frist]], a physician, have called his criticism of the [[2009 flu pandemic vaccine|H1N1 flu vaccinations]] unscientific.{{Cite news|url=http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/10/13/bill-maher-vs-the-flu-vaccine|work=The New York Times|first=Tara|last=Parker-Pope|date=October 13, 2009|title=Bill Maher vs. the Flu Vaccine|accessdate=April 1, 2010}} Infectious diseases expert [[Paul Offit]] has written that misinformation about vaccines from celebrities like Maher has put children at unnecessary risk. Offit says that celebrities like Maher are seen as "less credible" and would still be considered just "great entertainment" if they weren't joined by the former Director of the [[National Institutes of Health]], Dr. [[Bernadine Healy]] and influential pediatrician, [[Robert Sears (physician)|Dr. Robert Sears]].{{cite book|last=Offit|first=Paul|title=Deadly Choices: How the Anti-Vaccine Movement Threatens us all |publisher=Basic Books|authorlink=Paul Offit|pages=168–171}} [[Oncologist]] [[David Gorski]] criticized Maher's claims about vaccines several times in [[ScienceBlogs]], and when Maher received the Richard Dawkins Award in 2009, Gorski wrote it was inappropriate.{{cite web|last=Gorski|first=David|title=Bill Maher gets the Richard Dawkins Award? That's like Jenny McCarthy getting an award for public health|url=http://scienceblogs.com/insolence/2009/07/23/bill-maher-gets-the-richard-dawkins-awar|publisher=[[ScienceBlogs]]|accessdate=2013-03-20}} Skeptics, including mathematician and science writer [[Martin Gardner]],{{cite web|last=Gardner|first=Martin|title=Bill Maher: Crank and Comic|url=http://www.csicop.org/si/show/bill_maher_crank_and_comic|publisher=[[CSICOP]]|accessdate=2013-03-20}} [[neurologist]] [[Steven Novella]],{{cite AV Media|last=Novella|first=Steven|authorlink=Steven Novella|title=Podcast 218 |date=September 23, 2009|url=http://www.theskepticsguide.org/archive/podcastinfo.aspx?mid=1&pid=218|publisher=[[The Skeptics' Guide to the Universe]]|accessdate=2013-03-20|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121210011702/http://theskepticsguide.org/archive/podcastinfo.aspx?mid=1&pid=218|archivedate=December 10, 2012}} and magician [[Jamy Ian Swiss]] have also strongly rebuked Maher, characterizing him as anti-science, uninformed and potentially endangering the health of fans who take his "non-medical" advice.{{cite web|last=Swiss|first=Jamy Ian|title=Overlapping Magisteria|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DIiznLE5Xno|publisher=[[JREF]]|accessdate=2013-03-20}} Maher responded to the criticism, saying, "What I've read about what they think I'm saying is not what I've said. I'm not a germ theory denier. I believe vaccinations can work. Polio is a good example. Do I think in certain situations that inoculating Third World children against malaria or diphtheria, or whatever, is right? Of course. In a situation like that, the benefits outweigh costs. But to me living in Los Angeles? To get a flu shot? No."Slotek, Jim (October 28, 2009). [http://www.winnipegsun.com/entertainment/tv/2009/10/28/11548266-sun.html "Needling Bill Maher"]. ''[[Winnipeg Sun]]''. ===Views on 9/11 conspiracy theories=== Maher has been a critic of [[9/11 conspiracy theories]]. On October 19, 2007, Maher confronted several [[9/11 Truth movement|9/11 truthers]] and had them ejected from his show audience after they interrupted the live show numerous times by calling out from the audience. The incident drew significant media attention and praise from Fox News talk show host and frequent critic [[John Gibson (political commentator)|John Gibson]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,304240,00.html|title=Hat's Off to Bill Maher|date=October 22, 2007|publisher=Fox News|accessdate=January 17, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071225170927/http://www.foxnews.com/story/0%2C2933%2C304240%2C00.html|archivedate=December 25, 2007|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}} ==Influences== Maher has said his influences include [[Johnny Carson]], [[Robert Klein]],{{cite web|url=http://www.argusleader.com/story/blogs/scotthudson/2015/09/10/bill-maher-good-comedy-bad-america/71896076|title=Bill Maher: 'What's good for comedy is bad for America'|work=[[Argus Leader]]|author=Scott Hudson|date=September 10, 2015|accessdate=June 6, 2016}} [[Lenny Bruce]], [[Steve Allen]],{{cite web|url=https://scanlyze.wordpress.com/2007/01/25/comedian-bill-maher-talks-about-steve-allen-lenny-bruce-condi-rice-911|title=Comedian Bill Maher talks about Steve Allen, Lenny Bruce, Condi Rice, 9/11|work=Scanlyze|author=Henry Edward Hardy|date=January 25, 2007|accessdate=June 6, 2016}} [[Mort Sahl]],{{cite web|url=http://www.mortsahlofficial.com/honors.html|title=Mort Sahl - Honors|work=Mort Sahl official website|date=January 25, 2007|accessdate=June 6, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160322032117/http://www.mortsahlofficial.com/honors.html|archive-date=March 22, 2016|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} and [[George Carlin]].{{cite episode|title=episode 38|airdate=October 1, 2004|series=Real Time with Bill Maher|serieslink=Real Time with Bill Maher|network=[[HBO]]|season=2|number=18}} Comedians who have said they were influenced by Maher are [[Chris Rock]]{{cite web|url=http://www.vulture.com/2014/11/chris-rock-frank-rich-in-conversation.html|title=Chris Rock Talks to Frank Rich About Ferguson, Cosby, and What 'Racial Progress' Really Means|publisher=[[Vulture.com]]|date=November 30, 2014|accessdate=June 6, 2016}} and [[Seth MacFarlane]].{{cite web|url=http://m.huffpost.com/us/entry/1564907.html|title=Bill Maher Interviews Seth MacFarlane On CNN, Talks 'Family Guy' Raunch & Animation (VIDEO)|publisher=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=June 2, 2012|accessdate=June 6, 2016}} ==Personal life== [[File:BillMaherStarSept10.jpg|thumb|right|Maher next to his star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]] in September 2010]] Maher has never married.[http://piersmorgan.blogs.cnn.com/2011/07/12/clips-from-last-night-bill-maher-on-why-hes-never-been-married-and-american-innovation "Clips From Last Night: Bill Maher on why he's never been married... and American innovation"]. ''[[Piers Morgan Live]]''. [[CNN]]. July 12, 2011.[http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/gossip/side-dish-bill-maher-love-break-biggest-rule-married-article-1.382688 "Side Dish: Bill Maher is so in love, he may even break his biggest rule—get married!"], ''[[New York Daily News]]'', October 26, 2009. Regarding marriage, Maher is quoted on his website as saying, "I'm the last of my guy friends to have never gotten married, and their wives—they don't want them playing with me. I'm like the escaped slave—I bring news of freedom."{{cite web|url=http://www.billmaher.com|title=About: Bill Maher biography|publisher=billmaher.com|accessdate=August 25, 2013}} In 2003, he began dating former Playboy Cyber Girl [[Coco Johnsen]]. In November 2004, at the end of their 17-month relationship, Johnsen sued Maher for US$9 million for "pain and suffering" for alleged "insulting, humiliating and degrading racial comments". Her suit stated that Maher promised to marry her and father her children, support her financially and buy a house in Beverly Hills. Johnsen's suit also alleged that she quit her job as a flight attendant and occasional model to be with him.{{cite web|url=http://www.thesmokinggun.com/archive/1111041coco1.html|title=Bill Maher Hit With Palimony Suit|accessdate=January 3, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081221001246/http://www.thesmokinggun.com/archive/1111041coco1.html|archivedate=December 21, 2008|deadurl=no}} Maher's lawyers in their response, filed on November 23, 2004, in Los Angeles Superior Court said Maher is a "confirmed bachelor, and a very public one at that" who "never promised to marry [Johnsen] or to have children with her".{{cite web|last=Lehner|first=Marla|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,832690,00.html|title=Bill Maher: Ex-Girlfriend Is a Con Artist - Bill Maher|work=People|date=2004-11-29|accessdate=2015-07-01}} Maher's filing stated that, after the relationship had ended, Johnsen "launched a campaign to embarrass, humiliate, and extort ridiculous sums of money from Bill Maher". Johnsen had previously accused another former boyfriend of rape and kidnapping in 1997, and the charges were later dismissed for lack of evidence.[http://www.thesmokinggun.com/documents/crime/maher-ex-serial-shakedown-artist "Maher: Ex Is Serial Shakedown Artist"]. [[The Smoking Gun]]. November 29, 2004.[http://www.salon.com/2004/11/30/tues_72/ "The Fix"], ''[[Salon (website)|Salon]]'', November 30, 2004.Keller, Julie (November 30, 2004). [http://www.eonline.com/news/48746/bill-maher-cries-con "Bill Maher Cries 'Con'"]. [[E!]]. The lawsuit was dismissed on May 2, 2005.Hagan, Joe (April 9, 2012). [http://nymag.com/news/features/bill-maher-2012-4/index5.html "It Won't Hurt You. It's Vapor."] ''[[New York (magazine)|New York Magazine]]'', pg. 6.[http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,155492,00.html#ixzz2bWSKQe4J "Judge Dismisses $9M Lawsuit Against Bill Maher"]. [[Fox News]]/[[Associated Press]]. May 4, 2005. In 2005, Maher began dating [[Karrine Steffans]], best-selling author and former hip hop model.{{cite web|url=http://www.allreaders.com/topics/Info_35499.asp|title=Plot Summary of Confessions of A Video Vixen|last=Calhoune|first=Sandra|accessdate=January 8, 2009|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081205104113/http://www.allreaders.com/topics/info_35499.asp|archivedate=December 5, 2008|deadurl= no}}{{cite web|url=http://www.savvyinsider.com/article.php?op=viewArticle&article_ID=305|title=Bill Maher – Smart, Snide, Still Single|accessdate=January 3, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051108055750/http://www.savvyinsider.com/article.php?op=viewArticle&article_ID=305|archivedate=November 8, 2005}}[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/07/28/AR2005072802242.html A Bawdy Lifestyle, and How to Shake It] Washington Post; July 28, 2005 When commentators suggested there was a pattern to his dating because both his girlfriend and former girlfriend were black, Maher said, "People say I'm into black women. [[Robert De Niro]] is into black women. I'm just into women who are real, and they happen to be black." From 2009-11, Maher dated former adjunct professor, [[science education|science educator]], and current ''[[Skeptics' Guide to the Universe]]'' co-host [[Cara Santa Maria]].[http://www.intouchweekly.com/2011/03/bill_maher.php "Bill Maher & Cara Santa Maria Split"], ''[[InTouch Weekly]]'', March 21, 2011. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110906155003/http://www.intouchweekly.com/2011/03/bill_maher.php|date=September 6, 2011 }} In 2014, Maher was dating [[Ontario]]-born singer [[Anjulie|Anjulie Persaud]].{{cite web|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/1224401/toronto-mayor-rob-ford-gets-support-from-bill-maher|title=Bill Maher supports Rob Ford|publisher=[[Global News]]|date=March 22, 2014|first=John|last=Kennedy|accessdate=December 17, 2014}} In 2012, Maher purchased a minority ownership interest in the [[New York Mets]].{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/new-york/mlb/story/_/id/8004806/bill-maher-buys-minority-share-new-york-mets|title=Bill Maher owns stake in Mets|author=Rubin, Adam|publisher=[[ESPN New York]]|accessdate=June 4, 2012}} ==Bibliography== * ''[[True Story: A Novel]]'', 1994 ({{ISBN|0-7432-4251-3}}) * ''Does Anybody Have a Problem With That? Politically Incorrect's Greatest Hits'', 1996 ({{ISBN|0-679-45627-9}}) * ''Does Anybody Have a Problem with That? The Best of Politically Incorrect'', 1997 ({{ISBN|0-345-41281-8}}) * ''[[When You Ride Alone You Ride with bin Laden|When You Ride Alone You Ride With Bin Laden: What the Government Should Be Telling Us to Help Fight the War on Terrorism]]'', 2003 ({{ISBN|1-893224-90-2}}) * ''Keep the Statue of Liberty Closed: The New Rules'', 2004 ({{ISBN|1-932407-47-2}}) * ''[[New Rules: Polite Musings from a Timid Observer]]'', 2005 ({{ISBN|1-59486-295-8}}) * ''[[The New New Rules: A Funny Look at How Everybody but Me Has Their Head Up Their Ass]]'', 2011 ({{ISBN|0-39915-841-3}}) ==Filmography== {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="3" style="background:#B0C4DE;" | Film |- ! {{Western Buddhism}} [[File:P1010956 temple bouddhiste Lerab Ling et la vallee.JPG|thumb|250px|[[Lerab Ling]], in [[Montpellier]], [[Languedoc-Roussillon]].]] [[Buddhism]] is the fourth largest religion in [[France]], after [[Christianity]], [[Islam]], and [[Judaism]].
France has over two hundred [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] meditation centers, including about twenty sizable retreat centers in rural areas. The Buddhist population mainly consists of [[China|Chinese]], [[Vietnamese people|Vietnamese]], and [[Koreans|Korean]] immigrants, with a substantial minority of native French converts and "sympathizers." The rising popularity of Buddhism in France has been the subject of considerable discussion in the French media and academy in recent years.
==Demographics==
In the early 1990s, the [[French Buddhist Union]] (UBF, founded in 1986) estimated there to be 600,000 to 650,000 Buddhists in France, with 150,000 French converts among them.<ref name="globalbuddhism.org">Obadia, Lionel (2001). [http://www.globalbuddhism.org/jgb/index.php/jgb/article/view/30/38 Tibetan Buddhism in France: A Missionary Religion?], Journal of Global Buddhism 2, 92-109</ref> In 1999, sociologist [[Frédéric Lenoir]] estimated there are 10,000 converts and up to 5 million "sympathizers," although other researchers have questioned these numbers.<ref>Lenoir, Frédéric. Le bouddhisme en France.Paris: Fayard, 1999</ref> A 1997 opinion poll counted as sympathizers young people who feel "an intellectual affinity with Buddhism or expressed a sympathy to a Buddhist worldview."<ref>Opinion poll conducted by CSA La vie RTL: "Dieu intéresse-t-il les jeunes?" published in La vie, no. 2691, 27 March-2 April 1997, 18-30.</ref>
==History== [[Alexandra David-Néel]] was an important early French Buddhist. She is best known for her 1924 visit to the forbidden (to foreigners) city of [[Lhasa]], capital of [[Tibet]], and wrote more than 30 books about Buddhism, philosophy, and her travels. In 1911 Alexandra traveled to India, to further her study of Buddhism. She was invited to the royal monastery of [[Sikkim]], where she met Maharaj Kumar (crown prince) Sidkeon Tulku. She became Sidkeong's "confidante and spiritual sister" (according to Ruth Middleton), and perhaps his lover (Foster & Foster). She also met the thirteenth [[Dalai Lama]] twice in 1912, and had the opportunity to ask him many questions about Buddhism—a feat unprecedented for a European woman at that time.
In the late 1960s and early 1970s, Buddhist teachers of various traditions began to visit France, as detailed below.
==Zen Buddhist communities==
[[Taisen Deshimaru]] was a Japanese [[Zen Buddhist]] who founded numerous [[zendo]]s in France. [[Thich Nhat Hanh]] [[Vietnam]]ese-born Zen Buddhist nominated for the [[Nobel Peace Prize]] by [[Martin Luther King]], founded the [[Unified Buddhist Church]] (Eglise Bouddhique Unifiée) in France in 1969. [[Plum Village]], a monastery and retreat center in the [[Dordogne]] in southern France, is his residence and the headquarters of his international [[Sangha (Buddhism)|sangha]]. [[File:Temple des 1000 Boudhas 2.JPG|thumb|250px|[[Temple of One Thousand Buddhas]], in [[La Boulaye]], [[Saône-et-Loire]], [[Burgundy (French region)|Burgundy]].]]
==Tibetan Buddhist communities== By the late 1990s, it has been estimated that there are more than 140 [[Tibetan Buddhism|Tibetan Buddhist]] meditation centers in France. The first Tibetan Buddhist communities in France were established in the early 1970s. The highest-ranking head of schools to reside in France, [http://sakya-ngor.org/ H.E. Phendé Khenchen], established his temple of E Wam Phendé Ling in 1973. He is of the [[Ngor]] school of Buddhism. Buddhism in France's growth was catalyzed by visits, in 1975 of the [[Karmapa]] , head of the Kagyü school, [[Dudjom Rinpoche]] and [[Dilgo Khyentse Rinpoche]], also very high lamas, who visited [[Dordogne]], where they established retreat centers with the help of [[Pema Wangyal Rinpoche]]. [[Pema Wangyal Rinpoche]] is the son of [[Kangyur Rinpoche]], another high lama who was among the first to take western disciples. Dudjom Rinpoche later moved to France, where he passed away.
[[Kalu Rinpoche]], also a highly esteemed lama, visited France in 1971, 1972 and 1974 <ref>Kalu Rinpoche: Excellent Buddhism: An Exemplary Life, Clear Point Press 1995.</ref> and in 1976 led the first traditional three-year retreat for westerners in France. In the [[Kagyu]] lineage such retreats confer the title "lama" on those who complete them. It is estimated that sixty percent of the centers and monasteries in France are affiliated with the Kagyu school.<ref name="globalbuddhism.org"/> 1982 the [[Dalai Lama]] visted France.<ref>https://www.dalailama.com/the-dalai-lama/events-and-awards/travels/travels-1980-1989</ref>
There are about twenty retreat centres representing all the different schools as well as many town-based centres which are under the direction of great Tibetan Buddhist masters.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.lerabling.org/index.php?pid=77 |title= Lerab Ling profile of Tibetan Buddhism in France}}</ref> [[Dhagpo Kundreul Ling]] in Auvergne is said to be the biggest Buddhist monastery outside Asia.{{citation needed|date=September 2008}}<!--DEAD LINK<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ambafrance-au.org/article.php3?id_article=462 |title=French consulate "bout France Fact Sheet"}}</ref>-->
Some of the larger retreat centers are:
* [[Chanteloube]] (Songtsen) in Dordogne (founded by [[Dilgo Khyentse Rinpoche]]) * [[Dashang Kagyu Ling]] (Temple Des Milles Boudhas) in Bourgogne (founded by [[Kalu Rinpoche]]) * [[Dechen Chöling]] in Limousin (founded by [[Sakyong Mipham Rinpoche]]) * [[Dhagpo Dargye Ling]] in Archignac (founded by [[Shamar Rinpoche]]) * [http://www.dhagpo-dedrol.org Dhagpo Dedrol Ling] in Plazac (founded by [[Gendun Rinpoche]]) * [http://dhagpo-kundreul.org Dhagpo Kundreul Ling] in Auvergne (founded by Gendun Rinpoche) * [http://www.dhagpo-kagyu-ling.org Dhagpo Kagyu Ling] in Dordogne (founded by the 16th Karmapa (Karmapa's European Seat)) * [http://www.montchardon.org Karma Mingyour Ling] in Isère (Montchardon) (founded by Jean-Pierre Schnetzler and Kalu Rinpoche, under the spiritual guidance of Ven. Lama Teunsang) * [[Drukpa Plouray]] [[Pel Drukpay Tcheutsok]] in Brittany (founded by the [[Gyalwang Drukpa]] * [[Karma Kagyu Tendar Ling]] in Dordogne (founded by [[Karmapa]] [[Orgyen Trinley Dorje]]) * [[E Wam Phendé Ling]] in Normandy (founded by H.E. Phende Kenchen) * [[Karma Ling]] in Savoie (founded by Kalu Rinpoche) * [[Institut Vajra Yogini]] in the [[Tarn (department)|Tarn]] department (Lavaur) * [[Lerab Ling]] in [[Languedoc-Roussillon]] (founded by [[Sogyal Rinpoche]]) * [http://www.nalanda-monastery.eu Nalanda Buddhist Monastery] (Lavaur, Tarn District), founded by [[Lama Yeshe]] and [[Lama Zopa Rinpoche]] of the [http://www.fpmt.org FPMT] (the [[Foundation for the Preservation of the Mahayana Tradition]]) * [[Ogyen Kunzang Chöling]] in [[Alpes-de-Haute-Provence]] (founded by [[Robert Spatz]]) * [[Orgyen Samye Chöling (Laugeral)]] in Dordogne (founded by [[Dudjom Rinpoche]]) * [[Shechen Tennyi Dargyeling (La Sonnerie)]] in Dordogne (founded by [[Dilgo Khyentse Rinpoche]])
Monasticism has traditionally been the bedrock of Tibetan Buddhism, but there were only a few dozen ordained French monks and nuns until the mid-1990s. However, there are now at least 300, most of whom were trained at the two monasteries in Auvergne.<ref name="wwrn.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.wwrn.org/article.php?idd=14098&sec=52&con=2|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930185000/http://www.wwrn.org/article.php?idd=14098&sec=52&con=2|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2007-09-30|title="Buddhism in France is booming," World Wide Religion Network}}</ref>
The most famous French monk in the Tibetan Buddhist tradition is [[Matthieu Ricard]], a longtime student of Dilgo Khyenste Rinpoche who is the son of famous philosopher [[Jean-Francois Revel]]. He has published books on Buddhism which have contributed to interest in Buddhism and French Buddhists among the [[intelligentsia]].
==Media and national interest== "Wisdom of Buddhism", a weekly French TV program, draws about 250,000 viewers, according to the Buddhist Union of France.<ref name="wwrn.org" />
Philosopher [[Luc Ferry]], appointed Minister of Youth and Education in 2002, published an article in Le Point magazine in which he asked, "Why this Buddhist wave? And why particularly in France, a very Catholic country in the past? ... In this time of de-Christianization, Buddhism has furnished to the West a rich and interesting alternative."<ref name="wwrn.org" />
==Further reading== *{{cite journal |last1=Campergue |first1=Cécile |title=Le bouddhisme tibétain en France |journal=Histoire, monde et cultures religieuses |date=2013 |volume=1 |issue=25 |pages=137-168 |doi=10.3917/hmc.025.0137 |url=https://www.cairn.info/revue-histoire-monde-et-cultures-religieuses-2013-1-page-137.htm}} *Choron-Baix, Catherine (1991). De Forêts en banlieues. La Transplantation du Bouddhisme Lao en France, Archives de sciences sociales des religions 36 (73), 17-33
==Notes== <references/>
==External links== *[http://www.bouddhisme-france.org/ Buddhist Union of France (Union Bouddhiste de France)] *[http://www.centrebouddhisteparis.org/Le_Centre/liens/autres_centres_bouddhistes.html List of Buddhist Centres in France] *[http://sakya-ngor.org/ Ngor Ewam Phendé Ling temple.] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060514155329/http://www.whytraveltofrance.com/?page_id=431 List of French Kagyu centers] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130606151204/http://www.globalbuddhism.org/bib-bud.html Bibliography of Buddhism in France] {{Buddhism topics}} {{Buddhism in Europe}}
